newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Wheat contracts find no buyers on Belgrade bourse.
newsitem.headline: Wheat contracts find no buyers on Belgrade bourse.

text.p: The Belgrade Stock Exchange (BSE) reported no deals on Thursday in the first sale of wheat forward contracts aimed at raising funds to finance this year's sowing.
The Serbian Commodity Reserve Agency offered two tranches of wheat selling contracts, maturing July 15, 1997 worth nearly 150 million dinars ($29.77 million).
But traders said the lack of buyers caused no alarm and said the contracts need more aggressive marketing. A bourse official blamed the lack of interest on insufficient information.
"The details were published only yesterday and contracts will be on sale over the next two months," Goran Altaras of the BSE told Reuters.
Altaras said low buyer interest at the outset of the sale was expected because it was the first time securities with such a long maturity had been introduced.
According to earlier government statements, the agency was to finance the advance purchase of up to 1.2 million tonnes of the 1997 wheat crop by issuing wheat contracts.
The contract's face value is 9,000 dinars with 10 tonnes of wheat sold as collateral and carrying 32 percent interest.
The "D1" tranche of 5,500 individual contracts totalling 49.5 million dinars is reserved for buyers paying cash now.
A "D2" tranche of 11,000 contracts amounting to 99 million dinars is offered to investors paying in four instalments. Both will be on sale until December 3, the bourse said.
The contracts also provide the holder with an export licence.
A trader cited tight market liquidity as another reason for the lack of investor interest, but was optimistic that activity would soon emerge.
Many potential investors -- banks, flour mills and bakeries -- said introducing advance funding of the 1997 wheat crop was good and would prevent wheat prices surges.
Foreign investors cannot be first-hand buyers unless they have a company or some other outlet on Yugoslav territory.
